_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Roundys' Westville  Division, 6500 South  U. S. 421 Westville, In. 46391 is
situated on  21.5  acres. The area around Roundys' property is mostly flat treeless farmland.

    There are a few houses and some businesses within a half-mile of the property lines. There is a Correctional Facility about three quarters of a mile housing about 
2500 inmates.

    The town of Westville is north of this facility approximately 2.5 miles. There 
are about 800 residents in the town and about 600 rural residents. The town has a volunteer fire department and a Town Hall with three active Police Officers. There
are three Restaurants in Westville. Two of which are Truck Stop fueling stations.

    Roundys' warehouse employs approximately 400 associates. Their jobs would include Supervision and Management, Truck drivers and Truck / Trailer mechanics. Selectors for order picking, High Lift, Fork Truck Operators, Auditors and Vehicle and
Building Maintenance, Sanitation.

    This facility is a well-maintained and orderly operation. We have a low percent of accidents or injuries. The new hire training is top of the line with yearly training and documentation.

    All new employees are given a tour of the facility. During the tour they are shown
areas of high concentrations of ammonia, such as vessels, piping, and compressors. They
are also told of the hazards of ammonia and shown the evacuation routes in the event of a
release. 

    There are four meeting areas depending on wind direction. In each section of the
Facility are directional maps in frames mounted to the walls. Each associate knows the
meeting areas when the evacuation and wind direction are given over Public Address
System. The Public Address System has a generator back up system in the event of a power outage from the Utility Company (NIPSCO). Twice yearly an evacuation drill is
conducted. All associates must exit the building for the drill and go to a predesignated
meeting area until the all clear is given by the supervisor of their are

a of work assignment.  They are instructed to use the buddy system. If someone is missing from an 
area and is not at the meeting area, the Hazmat commander will be notified the team can make a rescue.

    The Hazmat  Team  Consists of a Commander, Captain, two Entry personal, two Decon personal, two Laision personal.  Also a  first aid and the Safety Director.

    The Hazmat Cart has over $60,000 in tools and rescue equipment. The team also has the local volunteer fire department to assist in any release situation. Also to assist is
the LaPorte county Hazmat team should the need arise for more responders.

    Roundys' has twelve cold storage rooms. The coldest room is the ice cream
room, labeled Freezer #1 which is 4,620 square feet. The warmest room is 45*. This
is the produce dock. The entire Perishable area is monitored with ammonia sensors. 
They are set at 50  P. P..M. and  wired to the Maintenance Department and  Security Control Center. 

    When an alarm registers at a location, it is investigated by a trained Maintenance 
Associate. All Maintenance Associates are trained to recognize and initiate an ammonia
evacuation  procedure should the need arise.

    There has not been any major ammonia releases at this facility for over ten years.

    There has been major modification to this facility with the addition of 135,000  square feet of cold storage. There are five ammonia compressors, 38 evaporators and 3 condensers. There are 1,159 valves associated with the ammonia system. All piping is of sound construction and 90% is under insulation.  There are two Engine rooms next to each other. One room has 3 Sullair 500 horse power compressors, the other has a 368 horse power compressor and a 305 horse power compressor.

    The three condensers are IMECO, with 3500 tons of refrigeration. All components are inspected yearly in our Mechanical Integrity Audit. It is controlled 
by the staff and an independent company (Fisher Refrigeration of South Bend In.). All discrepancies are d

elt with swiftly by the Maintenance Department.

    Daily logs are kept in the control room as to how many changes are made to the ammonia system. Forms are filled out for auto verses manual operation.

    The P.S.M. manuals are kept up to date on a daily basis. Records, work schedules, and procedures on the ammonia system are recorded and filed daily.  Also process-teaching logs are used to inform each shift of any new changes.

    This is a well maintained and highly respected facility. Many of our contractors
have noted how well documented and clean areas of ammonia are kept.
